title: 107_hr1209
content: The "Child Status Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It allows the use of age on petition filing date, parent's naturalization date, or marriage termination date to determine status as an immediate relative. Section 201 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include rules for determining the age of certain aliens for immediate relative classification. The age can be based on the petition filing date, parent's naturalization date, or marriage termination date. The age of certain aliens for immediate relative classification can be determined based on the parent's naturalization date or marriage termination date. The age of an unmarried son or daughter of a citizen for classification purposes is determined based on the alien's age at the date of the termination of the marriage. Treatment of unmarried sons and daughters seeking status as family-sponsored, employment-based, and diversity immigrants. Section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include rules for determining if certain aliens are children based on their age at the time an immigrant visa number becomes available. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include rules for determining the age of alien children for visa classification purposes. The petition process for alien children and derivative beneficiaries is outlined, including the retention of priority dates if the child ages out of their original category. The alien's category will be automatically converted, retaining the original priority date from the original petition. SEC. 4. USE OF AGE ON PARENT'S APPLICATION FILING DATE IN DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY FOR ASYLUM. Section 208(b)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow spouses and children of aliens granted asylum to receive the same status if not eligible for asylum themselves. Unmarried children under 21 seeking to join a parent granted asylum will continue to be classified as children. The amendment allows unmarried children under 21 seeking to join a parent granted asylum to be classified as children even if they turn 21 while the application is pending. SEC. 5 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow unmarried children under 21 seeking to join a parent granted asylum to be classified as children even if they turn 21 while the application is pending. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of classification petitions for unmarried sons and daughters of naturalized citizens. Section 204 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow petitions for unmarried sons and daughters of naturalized citizens to be converted to family-sponsored immigrant petitions if the parent becomes a citizen. The daughter can file a written statement with the Attorney General to elect not to have the conversion of the petition occur or to have it revoked if it has already occurred. The son or daughter's eligibility for admission as a family-sponsored immigrant will be determined as if naturalization had not taken place. The priority date for an unmarried son or daughter can be maintained if it was assigned before naturalization. This subsection applies to properly filed petitions regardless of approval status before naturalization. SEC. 7. Immigration benefits for certain alien children not affected. The Child Status Protection Act amendments shall not limit or deny any right or benefit provided under this subparagraph. SEC. 8. Effective date. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the enactment date and will apply to aliens who are derivative beneficiaries or beneficiaries of approved or pending petitions under the Immigration and Nationality Act.
